revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Angus Sampson | image = | imagesize = | occupation = {{hlist|Actor|director|producer|writer|voice-over artist}} | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|35|2014|12|06}} | years_active = 1998 - present | caption = | birth_place = [[Sydney]], Australia }} '''Angus Sampson''' (born 1978 or 1979){{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/angus-sampson-actor-35/story-e6frg8h6-1227143865521?nk=92db624443786903de066aa709cea346-1479140082|title=Angus Sampson, actor, 35|last=Rowbotham|first=Jill|work=[[The Australian]]|date=6 December 2014}} is an Australian actor, director, producer, writer, and voice-over artist. He had a supporting role in the [[Insidious (film series)|''Insidious'' film series]], the comedy crime drama film [[The Mule (2014 film)|''The Mule'']] (2014), the comedy film ''[[Now Add Honey]]'' (2015), the action film ''[[Mad Max: Fury Road]]'' (2015), and the supernatural horror film ''[[Winchester (film)|Winchester]]'' (2018). ==Early life== Sampson was born in [[Sydney]], Australia, and was educated at [[The Armidale School]] in northern New South Wales. He graduated from the AWARD School in 2002.{{cite web |title=Angus Sampson description |url=http://www.hollywoodpreviews.com/angus-sampson.html |work=Hollywood Previews |publisher=iMedia International |accessdate=10 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712213829/http://www.hollywoodpreviews.com/angus-sampson.html |archivedate=12 July 2011 }} ==Career== ===Film=== Sampson has had a diverse and distinct array of film roles, including ''[[Mad Max: Fury Road]]'', ''[[Now Add Honey]]'', ''[[Insidious (film)|Insidious]]'', ''[[Insidious: Chapter 2]]'', ''[[Insidious: Chapter 3]]'', ''[[Insidious: The Last Key]]'', ''[[The Mule (2014 film)|The Mule]]'', ''Summer Coda'', {{ cite web | date = 22 October 2010 | title = Summer Coda trailer | url = http://if.com.au/2010/10/22/article/DQLCPQJBGB.html | work = Inside Film | publisher = Intermedia | accessdate = 10 November 2010}}{{cite web |date=20 October 2010 |first=Jim |last= Schembri | title= Summer Coda review |url= http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/summer-coda-20101020-16tp8.html | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | publisher = Fairfax | accessdate = 11 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101027060213/http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/summer-coda-20101020-16tp8.html| archivedate= 27 October 2010 | deadurl= no}} ''[[Darkness Falls (2003 film)|Darkness Falls]]'', ''[[Razor Eaters]]'', ''[[Kokoda (film)|Kokoda]]'', and ''[[Footy Legends]]''. He was the [[suit actor]] for the role of Bull{{ cite web | year = 2010 | title = Angus Sampson CV | url = http://esvc000759.wic057u.server-web.com/cr/talent/actors/sampsona.asp | publisher = Creative Representation | accessdate = 9 November 2010}} in [[Spike Jonze]]'s ''[[Where the Wild Things Are (film)|Where The Wild Things Are]]''. Sampson was a special guest juror at the 2006 [[Melbourne International Film Festival]], and host of the 2010 [[Inside Film Awards|IF Awards]], broadcast on [[SBS Television#SBS Television|SBS TV]].{{ cite web |date=22 October 2010 |first=Sam |last=Dallas |title=Sampson to host IF Awards |url=http://www.if.com.au/2010/10/22/article/Angus-Sampson-to-host-IF-Awards/ZDQEEASRKX.html |work=Inside Film |publisher=Intermedia |accessdate=10 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101027004353/http://www.if.com.au/2010/10/22/article/Angus-Sampson-to-host-IF-Awards/ZDQEEASRKX.html |archivedate=27 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} In 2010 Sampson helped his friend [[Leigh Whannell]] develop an Australian "paranormal chiller" called ''[[Insidious (film)|Insidious]]''. ''[[Saw (2004 film)|Saw]]'' horror-writer Whannell{{ cite web | date = 30 October 2010 | title = Leigh Whannell: writer, actor, plumber | url = http://if.com.au/2008/10/30/article/LCZMUNEMXV.html | work = Inside Film | publisher = Intermedia | accessdate = 10 November 2010}} and Sampson are both former ''[[Recovery (TV series)|Recovery]]'' presenters. ''Insidious'' (previously called ''Vultures'') first screened in September 2010, with Whannell and Sampson playing "comical low-tech paranormal investigators" Specks and Tucker, roles they have reprised in the film's three follow-ups.{{ cite web | date = 16 September 2010 | first = Allan | last = Hunter | title = Insidious | url = http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/latest-reviews/insidious/5018312.article | work = Screen Daily | publisher = EMAP Media | accessdate = 11 November 2010}} ===Television=== Sampson's acting career launched in 1996 with role as [[Dylan Lewis]]'s balaclaved sidekick "The Enforcer" on ''[[Recovery (TV series)|Recovery]]'', an [[ABC (Australia)|ABC]] youth music show. Later television jobs include roles on ''[[The Secret Life of Us]]'', ''[[The 10:30 Slot]]'', He also appeared as [[Effie Stephanidis|Effie]]'s cousin Dimi in ''[[Greeks on the Roof]]'',{{ cite web | date = 10 July 2003 | title = AAPT thinks Effie's in touch with her publics | work = The Age | publisher = Fairfax | url = http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/07/09/1057430274273.html | accessdate = 11 November 2010}} and as Ali in an episode of ''[[Stingers]]''. Sampson was a popular performer and series winner on the improvised ''[[Thank God You're Here]]'' (Series: 1, 2, 3, & 4).{{cite news|last1=Kalina|first1=Paul|title=Actor Angus Sampson has thrived in Hollywood, but keeps one foot in Australia|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/actor-angus-sampson-has-thrived-in-hollywood-but-keeps-one-foot-in-australia-20141011-114a9g.html|accessdate=28 November 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=17 October 2014}} In 2007, Sampson portrayed television personality [[Ugly Dave Gray]] in the television movie ''[[The King (2007 film)|The King]]'' which examines the life of Australian TV legend [[Graham Kennedy]]. In the same year he also appeared in ''[[Wilfred (Australian TV series)|Wilfred]]''. In 2008 he played [[Leonardo da Vinci]] in the children's television series ''[[Time Trackers]]''. Sampson portrayed Michael Thorneycroft in the three final episodes of ''[[Underbelly (TV series)|Underbelly]]'', the series based on Melbourne's gangland war, 1995–2004. In 2012, he teamed up with [[Toby Schmitz]] reaching the semi-finals in Season 1 of the hilariously confusing Australian word game ''[[Randling]]'', hosted by [[Andrew Denton]] on ABC1. In 2015, Sampson starred on the [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] hit show ''[[Fargo (TV series)|Fargo]]'', playing the character Bear Gerhardt. === Radio === Sampson was an occasional co-host of Australian radio show ''[[Get This]]'' with [[Tony Martin (comedian)|Tony Martin]] on [[Triple M]].{{ cite web | date = 24 August 2006 | title = All aboard the party bus | work = The Age | publisher = Fairfax | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/tv--radio/all-aboard-the-party-bus/2006/08/22/1156012548121.html | accessdate = 11 November 2010}} Sampson was a founding member of The Forbidden Fruit, an experimental troupe whose only performance was a risque interpretation of ''Mad Max 2'' they performed on late night radio, in which Angus played The Lord Humungous, who turned out to be quite proficient with the jazz flute.{{Citation needed|date= February 2012}} Sampson has also been a presenter on [[Triple r|RRR]]'s [[Breakfasters]] program.{{ cite web | date = 6 August 2010 | title = Breakfasters | work = RRR FM | publisher = Libsyn | url = http://rrrfm.libsyn.com/breakfasters_6_august_2010 | accessdate = 31 October 2010}} In addition, Sampson was also the un-credited host of the cult classic late-night radio show ''The Lonely Hearts Club'', a deadpan comedy series which ran on ABC Radio National in early 2011 in which Sampson appeared under the pseudonym Richard Silk.[http://blog.australiantumbleweeds.com/?p=991 Australian Tumbleweeds] == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Film |- ! Year ! Title ! Result |- |rowspan=3|2014 |[[AACTA Awards|AACTA Award]] |[[AACTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role|Best Supporting Actor]] |rowspan=2|''[[100 Bloody Acres]]'' |{{nom}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2013/12/the-great-gatsby-the-rocket-lead-australian-academy-of-cinema-award-nominations-646155/|title=‘The Great Gatsby’, ‘The Rocket’ Lead Oz Academy Of Cinema Award Nominations|last=Tartaglione|first=Nancy|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=3 December 2013|accessdate=5 October 2017}} |- |rowspan=2|[[Australian Film Critics Association|AFCA Awards]] |Best Supporting Actor |{{nom}}{{cite web|url=https://www.if.com.au/nominations-announced-for-the-2014-australian-film-critics-association-awards/|title=NOMINATIONS ANNOUNCED FOR THE 2014 AUSTRALIAN FILM CRITICS ASSOCIATION AWARDS|author=|work=[[If Magazine]]|date=10 February 2014|accessdate=5 October 2017}} |- |Best Actor |''[[The Mule (2014 film)|The Mule]]'' |{{nom}}{{cite web|url=https://www.if.com.au/oz-critics-salute-the-babadook/|title=Oz critics salute The Babadook|last=Groves|first=Dan|work=[[If Magazine]]|date=8 February 2015|accessdate=5 October 2017}} |} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0760151|Angus Sampson}} * Angus Sampson [http://esvc000759.wic057u.server-web.com/cr/talent/actors/sampsona.asp Creative Representation CV] *{{Twitter|AngusSampson}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sampson, Angus}} [[Category:1970s births]] [[Category:Australian male film actors]] [[Category:Australian male television actors]] [[Category:Australian male voice actors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Male actors from Sydney]] [[Category:People educated at Trinity Grammar School (New South Wales)]]
